facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 201 and 202 of 1961 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 201 and 202 of 1961. Appeals from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and decree dated May 16, 1958 of Patna High Court in L.P. As. Nos 13 and 14 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeals from the judgment and decree dated May, 16, 1958 of the Patna High Court in L. P. As. Nos 13 and 14 of 1957.

facts.text: On November 14, 1951, Company Judge in Patna High Court ordered winding up of Gaya Sugar Mills Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: On November 14, 1951, an order was made by the Company Judge in the Patna High Court for the winding up of the Gaya Sugar Mills Ltd.

facts.text: On October 6, 1953, Company Judge ordered action under s. 153 of Indian Companies Act.

anchor.surface_text: On October 6, 1953, an order was made by the learned Judge for action to be taken under s. 153 of the Indian Companies Act.

facts.text: Mr. G. C. Banerjee appointed Chairman held meeting of creditors.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. G. C. Banerjee, who was appointed Chairman to hold the meeting of the creditors held separate meetings

facts.text: Separate meetings held for debenture-holders, secured creditors, and unsecured creditors.

anchor.surface_text: of the debenture- holders, secured creditors and of the unsecured creditors. In his Report he stated as regards

facts.text: Thirty unsecured creditors attended meeting in person or by proxy.

anchor.surface_text: the meeting of the unsecured creditors that thirty unsecured creditors either in person or through proxy attended and took part

facts.text: Resolution proposed by Standard Vacuum Oil Company, seconded by Shri K. C. Agarwal, passed by majority in number and three-fourths in value.

anchor.surface_text: in the meeting, and that ultimately a resolution proposed by one of the creditors, the Standard Vacuum Oil Company and seconded by another creditor Shri K. C. Agarwal was passed by the creditors present by majority in number as well as three-fourth in value.

facts.text: Arjun Prasad claimed to represent Bhandari Bros. and Hindustan Coal Company Ltd. at unsecured creditors meeting.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that at this meeting one Arjun Prasad claiming to represent two creditor companypanies, viz., Bhandani Bros., and the Hindustan Coal Company Ltd., cast his votes on behalf of these two companypanies, in support of the resolution.

facts.text: No objection taken at meeting to validity of Arjun Prasad's votes.

anchor.surface_text: No objection was taken at the meeting to the validity of these votes by any of the creditors who opposed the resolution and the Chairman proceeded on the basis that these votes were validly cast.

facts.text: If Arjun Prasad's votes valid, requisite three-fourths majority in value obtained.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that if these votes were number validly cast the requisite majority of three-fourths in value would number be obtained.

facts.text: Objection raised at final hearing by opposing creditors that Arjun Prasad's votes invalid.

anchor.surface_text: When the application came up for final hearing before the Court an objection was taken on behalf of creditors who opposed the scheme that the votes cast by Arjun Prasad on behalf of the two creditor companypanies, viz., Bhandani Brothers and the Hindustan Coal Company were number valid votes

facts.text: Company Judge opined sufficient explanation for late objection and held resolutions sufficient for valid voting.

anchor.surface_text: The Company Judge was of the opinion that there was numbersufficient explanation as to why the objection as to the validity of the votes was number taken earlier and so the objection raised at the late stage companyld number be entertained. On the merits also he held that the resolution passed by the creditor companypanies authorising Arjun Prasad, to attend the meeting of the unsecured creditors of the Gaya Sugar Mills Ltd., and vote on behalf of the companypanies, were sufficient in law to make his attendance at the meeting the attendance of the companypanies in person and his voting on behalf of the companypanies valid voting of the companypanies.

facts.text: Company Judge rejected the objection.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, he rejected this objection.

facts.text: Division Bench of Patna High Court allowed the objection on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal a Division Bench of the Patna High Court has allowed the objection, being of opinion that the delay in raising the objection would number entitle the Court to ignore the legal defect of the votes and that in law the votes cast by Arjun Prasad were number valid votes

facts.text: Division Bench held votes cast by Arjun Prasad not valid.

anchor.surface_text: of these two creditor companypanies, viz., Bhandani Brothers and the Hindustan Coal Company. A companytention that numberappeal lay to the High Court from the order of the Company Judge was rejected.

facts.text: Division Bench set aside Company Judge's order on this point.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the learned Judges set aside the order of the Company Judge as to this part of the case.

facts.text: Division Bench gave certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: They, however, gave a certificate that as regards the value and nature of the case, it fulfils the requirements of Art. 133 1  a  of the Constitution and is a fit one for appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on December 22, 1961 by DAS GUPTA, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. December 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-These appeals raise a question

facts.text: No proxy given by Bhandari Brothers and Hindustan Coal Company in accordance with Rule 150.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, numberproxy in accordance with Rule 150 was given by the two creditor companypanies, Bhandani Brothers and the Hindustan Coal Company, in the present case.

facts.text: Supreme Court held appeal from Company Judge lay to High Court, not Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: It necessarily follows that the appeal from the order of the Company Judge lay to the High Court and number to this Court. There is, therefore, numbersubstance in the first point raised on behalf of the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court held objection could be raised late despite laches.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the learned Judges who heard the appeal were right in thinking that however deplorable the delay by opposing creditors in raising the objection might be, that would number be a sufficient reason for refusing to entertain the objection.

facts.text: Supreme Court held resolutions by creditor companies did not make Arjun Prasad's voting valid as company's presence in person.

anchor.surface_text: The companyclusion of the High Court that the votes cast by Arjun Prasad on behalf of the two companypanies., viz., Bhandani Brothers and the Hindustan Coal Company, were number valid votes in our opinion, companyrect.

facts.text: Appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals are accordingly dismissed with companyts.

issues.text: the manner in which a creditor company can validly cast its vote at a meeting of the creditors held under the provisions of s. 153 of the Indian Companies Act, 1913

anchor.surface_text: These appeals raise a question as to the manner in which a creditor companypany can validly cast its vote at a meeting of the creditors held under the provisions of s. 153 of the Indian Companies Act, 1913.

issues.text: whether the appeal lay to this Court or the High Court

anchor.surface_text: The companytroversy is whether the appeal lay to this Court or the High Court. In other words, the question is, which is the authority authorised to hear appeals from the decisions of the Court ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Corporate entity lacks physical presence; 'present in person' under s.153(2) requires statutory mechanism like proxy rules, not general 'person' definition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No proxy per Rule 150; resolutions neither comply with proxy rules nor constitute statutory 'presence in person'; distinguished s.80 (members) and noted absence in 1913 Act unlike s.187(1956).

holdings.text: The votes cast by Arjun Prasad on behalf of the two companies, viz., Bhandani Brothers and the Hindustan Coal Company, were not valid votes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No valid proxy under Rule 150; no 'presence in person' per s.153(2); resolutions inadequate; requisite three-fourths majority in value not obtained without these votes.

The statutory provision in c2 specifying the appellate authority grounds the holding h1 that the appeal lies to the High Court rather than this Court.
The provision c2 on appeal forum directly addresses the issue i2 of whether the appeal lay to this Court or the High Court.
Section 3 defines High Court jurisdiction under Companies Act, grounding the holding that appeal from Company Judge lies to High Court
